subject: Re: Spelling
msgSnippet: Charles, Although I think you underestimate the anger that some have against what they believe to be American cultural imperialism, I basically agree with you:
messageBody:
Charles,

Although I think you underestimate the anger that some have against
what they believe to be American cultural imperialism, I basically
agree with you: NBC-English is a better base for phonemic writing
system than some historical dialect of English.

Today we have no way to break down the spelling LAUGH because we
have forgotten how to pronounce the gutteral GH. This knowledge
would be practically useless today anyway since no one pronounces
the word that way.

<laugh> should probably be phonemically spelled <laef, laaf, or
lawf> Or, we could allow [a] to cover all three pronunciations and
spel it <laf>.

- - - - - -

You are also correct in noting that there is a transition from
processing print letter by letter to processing whole words and
larger units as one becomes more adept and builds reading speed.

The purpose of phonemic spelling is to simplify the task of
beginning readers and to allow adults to pronounce written words
they have never heard spoken.

Steve
